bboxes.raw_text:
ATLANTA, Ca. = The nomina-
tion of Senator Barry Goldwater
as Republican candidate for
President is "both unfortunate
and disastrous Dr.. Martin
Luther King, Jr. said.


DR.. King. President of the
Southern Christian Leadership
Conference, told newsmen that
SCLC will campaign against
Coldwater and will ask its af-
filiates to cooperate.


The famed civil rights leader
has. never endorsed candidate
for the Presidency. but his Stout
rejection ofC oldwater is, he said,
ian indirect endorsement of
President Lyndon B. Johnson"


DR.. King stated, "It's both
unfortunate and disastrous that
the Republican Party has
nominated Senator Barry Cold
water as its candidate for the
Presidency of the United States.
In foreign policy. Mr.. Goldwater
advocates a narrow nationalism,
a Gripping isolationism and a
trigger-happy attitude that could
plunge the whole world into the
dark abyss of humiliation. On
social and economic issues, Mr..
G oldWater represents an un-
realistic conservatism that is
totally out Of touch with the
realities of the twentieth century.
The issue of poverty throughout
this land compels the attention of
all citizens of our country. 1t
is our conviction that Senator
Goldwater has neither the con-
Germ nor the comprehension
necessary to grapple with this
problem in the fashion that the
historical moment Dictates"

KING SAYS SCLC WILL
WORK AGAINST BARRY

Maricopa County has signed an
agreement with Salt River Pro-
iect and US. Bureau of Reclama-
ton permitting use of 90 miles
of canal rights of-way for public
recreation.


District Supervisor L. Alton
"Pat" Riggs hailed the action
and called the agreement "a
gigantic step toward utilization of
our canal system for the recrea-
tional benefit of all county
citizens.''


The board chairman COM
mended Victor Corbell. presi-.
dent, and the Salt River Project
staff, and A. B. West, regional
director, Bureau of Reclama-
ton, for their cooperation in
making the canal areas available
for public use.


In signing the agreement this
morning, Corbell declared, 1.-The
Project is happy to participate
in this program. Project canals
have been the lifeline of this
Valley since the 1905 and now,
in view of this agreement. they
are destined to be of even greater
benefit as the basis for much
needed recreation facilities in
this growing metropolitan area"


The 50-year permit enables
eventual development of parks
bordering the canals. The parks
would be spaced about four miles
apart. Each would contain a
lagoon fed by water from the
canal and would connect with
other lagoons by means of canal
paths. Facilities for horseback
riding hiking. fishing. picnicking
and boating will be provided.

NEW YORK = Despite the pleas
from Mayor Robert Wagner. who
had shortened his European trip,
Negroes in the city continued to
riot in the streets.


Action was conferred In
Brooklyn and a mounted unit was
called to maintain order.


Police shot and wounded Rufus
Weaver, %, one of three Negroes
officers claimed were footing

RIOTS CONTINUE IN new YORK
DESPITE PLEA FROM MAYOR

Robert Fowler, so, 1885 E.
Jackson, was charged with muir
der in the fatal shooting ofWillis
Lee Smith, 20.


Fowler claimed he found Smith
with his wife. BERTHE, AZ at the
home of a friend. 1880 E. Jack
son. He fired four shots at the
victim, who died of two shots in
the chest.

Fowler Charged
With Murder


In Fatal Shooting

a dry cleaning shop.


In Manhattan 500 white youths
shouted and tossed eggs, stones
and tin cans at 200 Negro pickets
outside of police headquarters.


Mayor Wagner pledged to en-
force law and prevent and punish
any police brutality. His address
was carried on the three ma ior
television networks.

toned the role of the FBI in
Mississippi. He said, "The FBI
hasn't been able to get enough
evidence to put anyone in jail.
You really begin wonder. what
good are they7 What are they
doing hereT "


In a letter to FBI Director ].
Edgar Hoover, Evers expressed
extreme shock at a recent state
ment of the law officer S in which
he is quoted as saying "lawless-
ness in the South is no worse than
lawlessness in the North"


1--WE must feel" declared
Evers. "that when the national
director of the FBI can make
statements such as this. the luna
tics who would deliberately de-
stroy human life or lloperty
are encouraged"


DR.. Henry cited half dozen
of the IA cases to the White
House last March in an effort
to get the federal government
to investigate the increased anti
Negro terrorism and violence in
Mississippi. These included:


Jasper Greenwood, so, pro-
prietor of Jasper's Lounge,
a Vicksburg Negro cafe. whose
body was found in a weed-grown
lot there last June %;


Allen Davis. native of ITALIA
hatchie County. who disappeared
from Darlie. MISS, in adjoining
Ouitman County. last June 27:


Clifford Walker. "a. Wilhn-
son County farmer. found shot to
death last March on a rural
road near his home:


Louis Allen, As, shot to death
in the front yard of his home
near Liberty in Amito County,
last January 81:


Two men, one whose body bore
gunshot wounds and the other
bruised about the face, found
dead, along with a woman, in an
auto on a rural road in Wilin-
son County.


Two other cases, involving the
alleged Staying of handcuffed
Negro prisoners by Law enforce
ment officers had been investi-
gated by Schwerner shortly be-
fore he disappeared.

NAACP Urges Investigation
In More Mississippi Deaths

CLARKSDALE. Miss. The
discovery to two brutally
murdered and mutilated bodies
of Negro citizens prompted new
calls for federal investigations
by the National Association for
the Advancement of Colored
People.


DR.. Aaron E. Henry, Missis-
sippi State NAACP president,
called upon Attorney General
Kennedy to find out who killed
Charles Moore, 20 and Henry
Dees, FL, and severed their
bodies. The lower halves of
both bodies we're found in the
Old River swamp near Tallulah.
La, Sunday and Monday, July
~ and l3.


Their mutilated bodies we're
discovered during the continuing
search for Michael Schwerner,
"a, and Andrew Goodman, 20.
both of New York. and James
Clancy, %. of Meridian, Miss,
who disappeared near Philadel-
phia, MISS, last June %.


In another move, in Jackson
Charles Evers, NAACP field
secretary, sent a. letter to Mis-
sissippi Governor Paul Johns on.
Monday, July Is, requesting that
he call upon the state lawmakers
to enact special legislation to
guarantee the safety of Missis-
sippi Negro citizens. MIR. Evers'
letter also asked for an early
meeting with the State Executive
to discuss the rising tide of anti
Negro violence.


Since his brother was shot in
the back by sniper outside of
his home in Jackson, June IL,
1868. Mr.. Evers said l4Negroes
have disappeared, been slain, or
have died mysteriously in rural
Mississippi.


Dr.. Henry said this fate has
befallen nine Negroes in the Delta
in the past seven months and in
none of the cases have arrests
been made.


"Most of these murders we're
committed by local police Of
ficers," Mr.. Evers asserted.
Also pointing to the fact that
no arrest has been made. the =
NAACP field secretary ques-

Mrs. Melissa Smith, president
of the Arizona-New Mexico an
nual conference, announces a
benefit fashion show will be held
at the Mas nic Temple, Sum-,
Aug. %. 3 pm. Donations are
81 and proceeds will go to the
$l0O parade of the annual con-
ference which will be held in
Tucson.
